body: Was coming here to report this. In my case, this is with `conpty` mode.
@parkovski Did you find this using conpty or winpty (it's winpty if you're not sure)?.

issue.title: alt_send_esc doesn't seem to work on Windows

body: I'm not sure if this is related but I have a vim key binding `ctrl+/` to toggle comments, it works fine in every terminal emulated I've used except Alacritty.

@luisdavim This issue only affects key combos with alt, not control. However, you might try binding `<C-S-_>` and/or `<Char-0x1f>`. If those don't work, maybe you could open a separate issue with details on your setup (vim/neovim, conpty/winpty, your alacritty.yml), because there are unfortunately many places that specific keybinding could go wrong.

issue.title: Alt-Space gets eaten on Windows
issue.body: On Windows, Alt-Space should always open the System menu for a window (i.e. the context menu attached to the window's icon in the very top-left corner). Alacritty is eating this gesture, and because I'm an Old, I can't use `Alt-Space, n` to minimize the window like I can for other windows

issue.title: Astral plane characters (e.g. emoji) canâ€™t be entered on Windows
issue.body:
I have WinCompose set up with <kbd>RAlt</kbd> as my Compose key, and various emoji shortcuts like <kbd><kbd>Compose</kbd>+<kbd>:</kbd>+<kbd>)</kbd></kbd> yields `ðŸ™‚`, <kbd><kbd>Compose</kbd>+<kbd>:</kbd>+<kbd>o</kbd></kbd> yields `ðŸ˜®`, *&c.*

I can also enter emoji using Windowsâ€™ emoji picker, <kbd><kbd>Win</kbd>+<kbd>.</kbd></kbd>.

When I use Windows Terminal (Preview), there are various known bugs with emoji, but overall it works.

But in Alacritty, when I enter emoji by any of these means, nothing happens. (I can type them elsewhere and paste them into Alacritty.)

I believe that characters outside the Basic Multilingual Plane are just being dropped. (Itâ€™s not the Compose key at fault; other BMP characters like `Î»` via <kbd><kbd>Compose</kbd>+<kbd>l</kbd>+<kbd>*</kbd></kbd> work.)

Probably related, keystrokes with Alt get eaten, though you can add key bindings for them to work around that: #1939, #1774. Iâ€™m a suspicious type and I suspect that the underlying cause is the same.

issue.title: alt_send_esc has no affect in Windows and other missing default keybindings
issue.body:
## Summary
Configuration option `alt_send_esc` does not have any affect in Windows and the default behavior is that no Alt key-chords work.

Somewhat related, `ctrl+space` should be `^@` and `ctrl+\` should be `\x1c` but they are not mapped.

This behavior is seen for both ConPTY and WinPTY backends.

### How the issue was verified

Use a minimal `alacritty.yml`:
```
enable_experimental_conpty_backend: true
alt_send_esc: true
```

Use `showkey -a` to see the result of the following key-chords:
- `alt+p`
- `alt+2`
- `alt+]`
- `alt-ctrl-f`
- `ctrl+space`
- `ctrl+\`
- `ctrl+b`
- `ctrl+d`

Results:
```
cmd> wsl.exe -e showkey -a

Press any keys - Ctrl-D will terminate this program

         32 0040 0x20
^\       28 0034 0x1c
^B        2 0002 0x02
^D        4 0004 0x04
```

With every other terminal emulator I tested, including the default for cmd.exe, I see the expected result:
```
cmd> wsl.exe -e showkey -a

Press any keys - Ctrl-D will terminate this program

^[p      27 0033 0x1b
        112 0160 0x70
^[2      27 0033 0x1b
         50 0062 0x32
^[]      27 0033 0x1b
         93 0135 0x5d
^[^F     27 0033 0x1b
          6 0006 0x06
^@        0 0000 0x00
^\       28 0034 0x1c
^B        2 0002 0x02
^D        4 0004 0x04
```

Toggling `alt_send_esc` between true and false and restarting Alacritty has no affect.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23530447/69000550-14c8a880-0897-11ea-8339-e8cc05c7c7ab.png)

Toggling `enable_experimental_conpty_backend` between true and false (WinPTY and ConPTY) has no affect. Proof both were tested:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23530447/69000879-83a80080-089b-11ea-8aaf-6eacbc0aa03d.png)

**Which operating system does the issue occur on?**
Windows 10 Pro version 1909

---

There seem to be several open and closed issues that mention this problem, but none of them are specifically addressing why `alt_send_esc` has no affect and a few control sequence mappings are missing in Windows .

https://github.com/jwilm/alacritty/issues/1939
https://github.com/jwilm/alacritty/issues/1774
https://github.com/jwilm/alacritty/issues/2390

body:
@CypherZealot could you provide the output of `alacritty --print-events | grep "ReceivedCharacter"` after pressing a couple of `alt` keys?

We'll probably have to report this upstream, but I just want to verify first that normal keys result in a `ReceivedCharacter` event, but when holding `alt` there is none.

> @CypherZealot could you provide the output of `alacritty --print-events | grep "ReceivedCharacter"` after pressing a couple of `alt` keys?
> 
> We'll probably have to report this upstream, but I just want to verify first that normal keys result in a `ReceivedCharacter` event, but when holding `alt` there is none.
If `alt` is a member of any key-chord nothing prints that matches the pattern `ReceivedCharacter`. Other key-chords do print. 

@chrisduerr, here is an example of the following sequence:
1. `b`
2. `ctrl+b`
3. `alt+b`
4. `alt+ctrl+b`
5. `ctrl+d`

```shell
alacritty.exe --print-events 2>&1 | grep "ReceivedCharacter"
[2019-11-16 18:35] [INFO] glutin event: WindowEvent { window_id: WindowId(WindowId(0xb01de)), event: ReceivedCharacter('b') }
[2019-11-16 18:35] [INFO] glutin event: WindowEvent { window_id: WindowId(WindowId(0xb01de)), event: ReceivedCharacter('\u{2}') }
[2019-11-16 18:35] [INFO] glutin event: WindowEvent { window_id: WindowId(WindowId(0xb01de)), event: ReceivedCharacter('\u{4}') }
```

Note the two missing events between `\u{2}` and `\u{4}`.

Nothing prints matching that pattern if the `Alt` key is held. 

---

If I define a keybinding:
```yaml
key_bindings:
  - { key: B, mods: Alt, chars: "\x1bb"  }
  - { key: B, mods: Alt|Control, chars: "\x1b\x02" }
```
And repeat the same sequence above, I can see `^[b` and `^[^B` prints in `showkey -a` but I get the same result from the `RecievedCharacter` pattern match as before, nothing prints when `Alt` is held.

I tried this in both WinPTY and ConPTY with the same result as well as with `alt_send_esc` true and false.

issue.title: Windows not sending characters with alt/control held

labels.name: C - needs investigation
labels.description: Issue must be confirmed and researched

repository.name: winit
repository.description: Window handling library in pure Rust

issue.body:
It appears that when pressing characters while holding `alt` or `ctrl` on windows, the `ReceivedCharacter` is not triggered for that specific character. However all other platforms seem to emit the pressed character.

For Alacritty this distinction is quite important, since alt can be sent to send escapes directly to the terminal.

This has been reported to Alacritty in https://github.com/jwilm/alacritty/issues/1939.
